stories.text:
Consider these two scenarios:

1. You decide to start a company with your childhood friend who you know very well.

2. You decide to start a company with a person you met online just a few weeks ago. You both click and decide to work together.

In both of the above scenarios what frank and candid discussion would you have with your co-founder before starting the company? How will the discussion in these two scenarios differ keeping in mind that one is a childhood friend and the other is a stranger?
stories.title: Ask HN: What frank discussion would you have with these two types of co-founders

stories.text:
Since they're not documenting this anywhere, I figured I'll let google do its thing and index this piece of info:

During the initial month (the "free" trial) on Fastmail, they make use of an "intensive" spam filtering system that can delay your emails from being sent by days (or not being sent at all).

When contacting support, this is all expected and nothing the user can do.

So essentially, due to this policy, Fastmail's "free trial" is useless, as the mail is neither "fast" nor, in some cases, "deliverable".

I can't speak of its service after the first month, but who* in their right mind would give money to a company that has such an unreliable delivery of emails (even if temporarily) ?

* here, by "who" I mean new customers, not existing ones that "never had a problem", of course
stories.title: PSA: On the Free Trial of Fastmail
People who know how the news is made resist conspiratorial thinking (2017)
